text: <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is one of the growth factors that controls the proliferation and differentiation of hematopoietic cells and <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , also known as <extra_id_0> Tcl-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> Tal-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is a transcription factor involved in erythropoiesis .

In this report , we studied the role of <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the proliferation of human peripheral blood burst - forming unit-erythroid ( BFU-E ) and the effects of <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in proliferating erythroid cells .

text: BFU-E - derived colonies increase progressively in size , as determined by cell number , from day 7 to day 14 of culture , with the greatest increase in colony size ( 10-fold expansion ) occurring between day 7 and day 10 .

<extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein levels in BFU-E - derived cells were highest in day 7 cells and decreased progressively from day 7 to day 14 of culture , suggesting an association of <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with erythroid proliferation .

In contrast , <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels did not decrease significantly between day 7 and day 14 cells , suggesting that posttranscriptional mechanisms are largely responsible for the decrease in <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein observed .

text: The role of <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced erythroid proliferation was then examined .
In BFU-E - derived colonies cultured with <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , colony size was significantly increased compared to control .

In day 7 and day 10 erythroid precursors cultured with <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein was increased significantly compared to control .

The increase in <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein levels in early erythroid precursors stimulated with <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suggests one mechanism through which <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may enhance normal erythroid proliferation .

<extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels assessed by Northern blot in day 7 cells did not increase significantly in response to <extra_id_0> Steel factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation , suggesting that posttranscriptional mechanisms may also be important in the increase in <extra_id_0> SCL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein observed in response to <extra_id_0> Steel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
